data.author: blissful
data.content: borders & southern petroleum i noted this week that two modestly bullish signals were mentioned in rns announcements, firstly their largest shareholder, alan brimacombe increased his stake to 15.08276% (14.067%) and ned will holden bought 1.5m shares making 2.5m in total. in themselves they aren’t massively important, the amount held by will holden is still quite small beer but for mr brimacombe to add to an already substantial stake rings a few bells for me, a very confident signal if ever there was one. readers will know that b&s has a formidable stake in the southern falklands basin where they own 3 production licences which includes 100% of the potentially huge darwin gas condensate discovery and and they in total have an area of some 10/- square km. within this there are a number of low risk, high impact prospects that will appeal to a number of industry interested parties. what has changed for b&s is the recent activity up at sea lion, the famous rockhopper discovery which following a landmark farm-in by navitas has now taken fid and is fully funded to get up and running. b&s are running a farm-out process which in the light of activity noted at sea lion has become a genuinely realistic, substantial project. when harry baker took over as ceo i went to see him, actually more importantly, his rocks people, who gave me a hugely impressive presentation on darwin and the adjacent acreage which i strongly advise potential investors to look at on the website. i think that borders is looking a very interesting opportunity, it is not without risk as success is predicated on a farm-out of darwin but should that happen then the upside will be substantial. i think that all the chips are in place for this happening, it is one of very few ‘big’ projects that i think would appeal to super majors and national companies alike. shell noted yesterday that big barrels are needed for a industry that ain’t going away, even the iea has capitulated and this week at a conference has confirmed that it has rowed away from its ludicrous forecasts over the last five years. compared to the complications in venezuela and other geographies the deep water prospects in the south atlantic must look appealing, put simply there are just not many opportunities of this size around right now. following the sea lion activity there are now fewer plays available in the area, the development there will not only open up that project but will make the southern basin look increasingly attractive, borders has the look of the cheapest house on the street in what is undoubtedly an upwardly mobile area. after a massive early run after the new ceo arrived the shares have settled down somewhat, indeed they are down 5% on a month and 10% on six months but on a year they are still up just over 40%. this will be knocked into the proverbial ****ed hat if the company were to announce a farm-out, admittedly this is no certainty but i think that the risk/reward is worth a

data.author: Mogger
data.content: Gus, Even if we are not in a "closed  period" NED's are prohibited from dealing if they are in possession of inside information. Its part of the UK Market Abuse Regulation and AIM rules - especially Rule 21. Therefore, Will Hodson knows there is nothing going on in the company( which is price sensitive) more than is currently in the public domain. That is not what we wanted to hear. Only five months to go until  more funds are required. Harry is certainly taking this one to the wire!. Mogger

data.author: gus0
data.content: Hi, LTT i dont think you should base your geology on a bright spot on Darwin West! But as you say it all needs to be proved up with an appraisal and that indeed is the share price's achilles heel even though its almost a dead cert. There was some kind of flow test done according to Bruce when it was drilled and for the life of me i cant remember the terminology he put behind it but the flow rate is huge which means we need less wells to pump more (and much more than RKH waxy crude i have to say) Fact of the matter is- 40% of the company is owned by people you can count on one hand, these guys are loaded and aren't looking at selling on the cheap. Then there's the entry investors, those poor folk who paid top dollar for stock here ( those up to 80p odd per share). Then there's the less than notified holders who add up to a substantial holding that wont sell on the cheap either. This then leaves a minority in my opinion for any reasonable deal. You need to remember that RKH  already got an upfront payment of 230 million dollars and 722 million development funding (which didnt happen) for their first farmout, hence why they got nothing upfront again for the second one! The scenario is totally different here,  lets see what transpires!

data.content: Gus, I thin that kind of evaluation, might be a little off without another appraisal well, any new player will not come in and pay 35p a barrel for the whole 470m barrels as that includes Darwin West which is not confirmed and in the bag, by any stretch of the imagination! So, working on the assumption a player would pay 50p a barrel for lets say 260m barrels, nothing for Darwin West as it's just a bright spot on seismic, then you have about 26p a share. Maybe add on an extra 5p for the other prospects and Darwin West and you are looking at 31p a share. I think a lot of folk would got for that I'm afraid. If you consider that RKH got nothing per barrel for giving away 65% on their entire acreage on a fully appraised Sea Lion and a discovery on Isobel, yet to be appraised, for a loan that pays 66% for their cost to first oil, we would be extremely lucky to get an offer over 40p. Never say never, I would be over the moon with an offer of 50p a share, but I also have to be realistic and look around. data.author: blissful
data.content: There is quite a lot to digest but it's worth reading up about Darwin and gas condensate on the website. The last 2 paragraphs: 'Based on an independent resource assessment of the combined Darwin East and Darwin West fault blocks, the estimated un-risked (P5O) recoverable resource is 462 million barrels of liquids (the liquids comprise of 296 MMbbs of liquid condensate and 166 MMbbls of LPG) A number of development scenarios have been considered, including the full development of Darwin East and Darwin West or a phased development. Engineering studies have demonstrated that the discovery, if successfully appraised, could be commercialised by a straightforward FPSO development, utilising proven, off-the-shelf technology. The liquids would be produced and the dry gas re-injected back into the reservoir'. https://bordersandsouthern.com/darwin-gas-condensate-discovery/

data.author: blissful
data.content: Yes, I agree about Malcy. He doesn't always get it right but this is a business where things are seldom a dead cert. Malcy has been through the presentation on Darwin so he knows how lucrative this could turn out to be. He is not ramping it but giving risk/reward opinion. Isn't that why people invest in plays like this? If there was no risk the sp would have flown away already! In my opinion only; I am almost 100% certain one of the majors will seize the opportunity of capitalising on the discovery, this is not a wild cat, especially now that things are getting going at Rockhopper. data.author: blissful
data.content: borders & southern petroleum i noted this week that two modestly bullish signals were mentioned in rns announcements, firstly their largest shareholder, alan brimacombe increased his stake to 15.08276% (14.067%) and ned will holden bought 1.5m shares making 2.5m in total. in themselves they aren’t massively important, the amount held by will holden is still quite small beer but for mr brimacombe to add to an already substantial stake rings a few bells for me, a very confident signal if ever there was one. readers will know that b&s has a formidable stake in the southern falklands basin where they own 3 production licences which includes 100% of the potentially huge darwin gas condensate discovery and and they in total have an area of some 10/- square km. within this there are a number of low risk, high impact prospects that will appeal to a number of industry interested parties. what has changed for b&s is the recent activity up at sea lion, the famous rockhopper discovery which following a landmark farm-in by navitas has now taken fid and is fully funded to get up and running. b&s are running a farm-out process which in the light of activity noted at sea lion has become a genuinely realistic, substantial project. when harry baker took over as ceo i went to see him, actually more importantly, his rocks people, who gave me a hugely impressive presentation on darwin and the adjacent acreage which i strongly advise potential investors to look at on the website. i think that borders is looking a very interesting opportunity, it is not without risk as success is predicated on a farm-out of darwin but should that happen then the upside will be substantial. i think that all the chips are in place for this happening, it is one of very few ‘big’ projects that i think would appeal to super majors and national companies alike. shell noted yesterday that big barrels are needed for a industry that ain’t going away, even the iea has capitulated and this week at a conference has confirmed that it has rowed away from its ludicrous forecasts over the last five years. compared to the complications in venezuela and other geographies the deep water prospects in the south atlantic must look appealing, put simply there are just not many opportunities of this size around right now. following the sea lion activity there are now fewer plays available in the area, the development there will not only open up that project but will make the southern basin look increasingly attractive, borders has the look of the cheapest house on the street in what is undoubtedly an upwardly mobile area. after a massive early run after the new ceo arrived the shares have settled down somewhat, indeed they are down 5% on a month and 10% on six months but on a year they are still up just over 40%. this will be knocked into the proverbial ****ed hat if the company were to announce a farm-out, admittedly this is no certainty but i think that the risk/reward is worth a

Therefore, Will Hodson knows there is nothing going on in the company( which is price sensitive) more than is currently in the public domain. That is not what we wanted to hear. Only five months to go until  more funds are required. Harry is certainly taking this one to the wire!. Mogger

data.author: gus0
data.content: Hi, LTT i dont think you should base your geology on a bright spot on Darwin West! But as you say it all needs to be proved up with an appraisal and that indeed is the share price's achilles heel even though its almost a dead cert. There was some kind of flow test done according to Bruce when it was drilled and for the life of me i cant remember the terminology he put behind it but the flow rate is huge which means we need less wells to pump more (and much more than RKH waxy crude i have to say) Fact of the matter is- 40% of the company is owned by people you can count on one hand, these guys are loaded and aren't looking at selling on the cheap. Then there's the entry investors, those poor folk who paid top dollar for stock here ( those up to 80p odd per share). Then there's the less than notified holders who add up to a substantial holding that wont sell on the cheap either. This then leaves a minority in my opinion for any reasonable deal. You need to remember that RKH  already got an upfront payment of 230 million dollars and 722 million development funding (which didnt happen) for their first farmout, hence why they got nothing upfront again for the second one! The scenario is totally different here,  lets see what transpires!

data.author: longtermthinker
data.content: Gus, I thin that kind of evaluation, might be a little off without another appraisal well, any new player will not come in and pay 35p a barrel for the whole 470m barrels as that includes Darwin West which is not confirmed and in the bag, by any stretch of the imagination! So, working on the assumption a player would pay 50p a barrel for lets say 260m barrels, nothing for Darwin West as it's just a bright spot on seismic, then you have about 26p a share. Maybe add on an extra 5p for the other prospects and Darwin West and you are looking at 31p a share. I think a lot of folk would got for that I'm afraid. If you consider that RKH got nothing per barrel for giving away 65% on their entire acreage on a fully appraised Sea Lion and a discovery on Isobel, yet to be appraised, for a loan that pays 66% for their cost to first oil, we would be extremely lucky to get an offer over 40p. Never say never, I would be over the moon with an offer of 50p a share, but I also have to be realistic and look around. In this climate of anti oil and anti investment in oil, whom would have thought RKH would be at 66p with first oil in 2 years with the funds and the partner to do it? Crazy times. LTT

data.author: blissful
data.content: There is quite a lot to digest but it's worth reading up about Darwin and gas condensate on the website. The last 2 paragraphs: 'Based on an independent resource assessment of the combined Darwin East and Darwin West fault blocks, the estimated un-risked (P5O) recoverable resource is 462 million barrels of liquids (the liquids comprise of 296 MMbbs of liquid condensate and 166 MMbbls of LPG) A number of development scenarios have been considered, including the full development of Darwin East and Darwin West or a phased development. Engineering studies have demonstrated that the discovery, if successfully appraised, could be commercialised by a straightforward FPSO development, utilising proven, off-the-shelf technology. The liquids would be produced and the dry gas re-injected back into the reservoir'. https://bordersandsouthern.com/darwin-gas-condensate-discovery/

data.author: blissful
data.content: Yes, I agree about Malcy. He doesn't always get it right but this is a business where things are seldom a dead cert. What I find very interesting is that he has done quite a large write up before any RNS! This is excellent for us as we have a chance to add while the sp is still low. Of course, it may be nothing, and he says it depends on the farm out,  but he does have a nose for these sorts of things and being friendly with Harry Baker who appeared to clam up is a tell tale sign something could be in the  air.  Malcy has been through the presentation on Darwin so he knows how lucrative this could turn out to be. He is not ramping it but giving risk/reward opinion. Isn't that why people invest in plays like this? If there was no risk the sp would have flown away already! In my opinion only; I am almost 100% certain one of the majors will seize the opportunity of capitalising on the discovery, this is not a wild cat, especially now that things are getting going at Rockhopper. Incidentally, May 10th 2010 I made £90k on the Sea Lion discovery - bought RKH at circa 30p and sold at £3.80. I hoping for something along those lines here.

data.author: blissful
data.content: borders & southern petroleum i noted this week that two modestly bullish signals were mentioned in rns announcements, firstly their largest shareholder, alan brimacombe increased his stake to 15.08276% (14.067%) and ned will holden bought 1.5m shares making 2.5m in total. in themselves they aren’t massively important, the amount held by will holden is still quite small beer but for mr brimacombe to add to an already substantial stake rings a few bells for me, a very confident signal if ever there was one. readers will know that b&s has a formidable stake in the southern falklands basin where they own 3 production licences which includes 100% of the potentially huge darwin gas condensate discovery and and they in total have an area of some 10/- square km. within this there are a number of low risk, high impact prospects that will appeal to a number of industry interested parties. what has changed for b&s is the recent activity up at sea lion, the famous rockhopper discovery which following a landmark farm-in by navitas has now taken fid and is fully funded to get up and running. b&s are running a farm-out process which in the light of activity noted at sea lion has become a genuinely realistic, substantial project. when harry baker took over as ceo i went to see him, actually more importantly, his rocks people, who gave me a hugely impressive presentation on darwin and the adjacent acreage which i strongly advise potential investors to look at on the website. i think that borders is looking a very interesting opportunity, it is not without risk as success is predicated on a farm-out of darwin but should that happen then the upside will be substantial. i think that all the chips are in place for this happening, it is one of very few ‘big’ projects that i think would appeal to super majors and national companies alike. shell noted yesterday that big barrels are needed for a industry that ain’t going away, even the iea has capitulated and this week at a conference has confirmed that it has rowed away from its ludicrous forecasts over the last five years. compared to the complications in venezuela and other geographies the deep water prospects in the south atlantic must look appealing, put simply there are just not many opportunities of this size around right now. following the sea lion activity there are now fewer plays available in the area, the development there will not only open up that project but will make the southern basin look increasingly attractive, borders has the look of the cheapest house on the street in what is undoubtedly an upwardly mobile area. after a massive early run after the new ceo arrived the shares have settled down somewhat, indeed they are down 5% on a month and 10% on six months but on a year they are still up just over 40%. this will be knocked into the proverbial ****ed hat if the company were to announce a farm-out, admittedly this is no certainty but i think that the risk/reward is worth a

data.author: BrightSpot
data.content: The value in Borders is developing the acerage and extracting the hydrocarbons. I would suggest a takeover is the last thing we want right now. I have never experienced a takeover with 100%, 200%, 300% premiums in the oil and gas business. That does not happen. We need Borders to farm out, have good financial carries and keep in the region of 20% of the joint venture. That’s realistic and will get the share price moving significantly. Logic tells me that’s a stretch but as an investor I’m looking for this. Q1 is very important to get something moving for Borders.

data.author: gus0
data.content: Hi, LTT i dont think you should base your geology on a bright spot on Darwin West! But as you say it all needs to be proved up with an appraisal and that indeed is the share price's achilles heel even though its almost a dead cert. There was some kind of flow test done according to Bruce when it was drilled and for the life of me i cant remember the terminology he put behind it but the flow rate is huge which means we need less wells to pump more (and much more than RKH waxy crude i have to say) Fact of the matter is- 40% of the company is owned by people you can count on one hand, these guys are loaded and aren't looking at selling on the cheap. Then there's the entry investors, those poor folk who paid top dollar for stock here ( those up to 80p odd per share). Then there's the less than notified holders who add up to a substantial holding that wont sell on the cheap either. This then leaves a minority in my opinion for any reasonable deal. You need to remember that RKH  already got an upfront payment of 230 million dollars and 722 million development funding (which didnt happen) for their first farmout, hence why they got nothing upfront again for the second one! The scenario is totally different here,  lets see what transpires!

data.author: longtermthinker
data.content: Gus, I thin that kind of evaluation, might be a little off without another appraisal well, any new player will not come in and pay 35p a barrel for the whole 470m barrels as that includes Darwin West which is not confirmed and in the bag, by any stretch of the imagination! So, working on the assumption a player would pay 50p a barrel for lets say 260m barrels, nothing for Darwin West as it's just a bright spot on seismic, then you have about 26p a share. Maybe add on an extra 5p for the other prospects and Darwin West and you are looking at 31p a share. I think a lot of folk would got for that I'm afraid. If you consider that RKH got nothing per barrel for giving away 65% on their entire acreage on a fully appraised Sea Lion and a discovery on Isobel, yet to be appraised, for a loan that pays 66% for their cost to first oil, we would be extremely lucky to get an offer over 40p. Never say never, I would be over the moon with an offer of 50p a share, but I also have to be realistic and look around. In this climate of anti oil and anti investment in oil, whom would have thought RKH would be at 66p with first oil in 2 years with the funds and the partner to do it? Crazy times. LTT

data.author: blissful
data.content: There is quite a lot to digest but it's worth reading up about Darwin and gas condensate on the website. The last 2 paragraphs: 'Based on an independent resource assessment of the combined Darwin East and Darwin West fault blocks, the estimated un-risked (P5O) recoverable resource is 462 million barrels of liquids (the liquids comprise of 296 MMbbs of liquid condensate and 166 MMbbls of LPG) A number of development scenarios have been considered, including the full development of Darwin East and Darwin West or a phased development. Engineering studies have demonstrated that the discovery, if successfully appraised, could be commercialised by a straightforward FPSO development, utilising proven, off-the-shelf technology. The liquids would be produced and the dry gas re-injected back into the reservoir'. https://bordersandsouthern.com/darwin-gas-condensate-discovery/

data.author: blissful
data.content: Yes, I agree about Malcy. He doesn't always get it right but this is a business where things are seldom a dead cert. What I find very interesting is that he has done quite a large write up before any RNS! This is excellent for us as we have a chance to add while the sp is still low. Of course, it may be nothing, and he says it depends on the farm out,  but he does have a nose for these sorts of things and being friendly with Harry Baker who appeared to clam up is a tell tale sign something could be in the  air.  Malcy has been through the presentation on Darwin so he knows how lucrative this could turn out to be. He is not ramping it but giving risk/reward opinion. Isn't that why people invest in plays like this? If there was no risk the sp would have flown away already! In my opinion only; I am almost 100% certain one of the majors will seize the opportunity of capitalising on the discovery, this is not a wild cat, especially now that things are getting going at Rockhopper. Incidentally, May 10th 2010 I made £90k on the Sea Lion discovery - bought RKH at circa 30p and sold at £3.80. I hoping for something along those lines here.

data.author: blissful
data.content: borders & southern petroleum i noted this week that two modestly bullish signals were mentioned in rns announcements, firstly their largest shareholder, alan brimacombe increased his stake to 15.08276% (14.067%) and ned will holden bought 1.5m shares making 2.5m in total. in themselves they aren’t massively important, the amount held by will holden is still quite small beer but for mr brimacombe to add to an already substantial stake rings a few bells for me, a very confident signal if ever there was one. readers will know that b&s has a formidable stake in the southern falklands basin where they own 3 production licences which includes 100% of the potentially huge darwin gas condensate discovery and and they in total have an area of some 10/- square km. within this there are a number of low risk, high impact prospects that will appeal to a number of industry interested parties. what has changed for b&s is the recent activity up at sea lion, the famous rockhopper discovery which following a landmark farm-in by navitas has now taken fid and is fully funded to get up and running. b&s are running a farm-out process which in the light of activity noted at sea lion has become a genuinely realistic, substantial project. when harry baker took over as ceo i went to see him, actually more importantly, his rocks people, who gave me a hugely impressive presentation on darwin and the adjacent acreage which i strongly advise potential investors to look at on the website. i think that borders is looking a very interesting opportunity, it is not without risk as success is predicated on a farm-out of darwin but should that happen then the upside will be substantial. i think that all the chips are in place for this happening, it is one of very few ‘big’ projects that i think would appeal to super majors and national companies alike. shell noted yesterday that big barrels are needed for a industry that ain’t going away, even the iea has capitulated and this week at a conference has confirmed that it has rowed away from its ludicrous forecasts over the last five years. compared to the complications in venezuela and other geographies the deep water prospects in the south atlantic must look appealing, put simply there are just not many opportunities of this size around right now. following the sea lion activity there are now fewer plays available in the area, the development there will not only open up that project but will make the southern basin look increasingly attractive, borders has the look of the cheapest house on the street in what is undoubtedly an upwardly mobile area. after a massive early run after the new ceo arrived the shares have settled down somewhat, indeed they are down 5% on a month and 10% on six months but on a year they are still up just over 40%. this will be knocked into the proverbial ****ed hat if the company were to announce a farm-out, admittedly this is no certainty but i think that the risk/reward is worth a

It might interest you that a certain mogger made the same arguments on here about the cash and licences 18 months ago.....and was 100% wrong, which of course he didnt like when pointed out to him.

Full disclosure I've nearly completed switching all my Borders shares to RKH so I'm not exactly impartial.
